中国科技巨头腾讯周三公布了季度业绩。
Nurphoto | Nurphoto |盖蒂图片社

腾讯周三公布季度收入增长 11%，创下一年多以来的最快增长，该公司在支付量、广告销售和游戏方面出现大幅反弹。

以下是腾讯在第一季度的表现，与 Refinitiv 的普遍预期相比：

  • 收入：1500 亿元人民币（214 亿美元），预期为 1460.9 亿元人民币，同比增长 11%。
  • 公司权益持有人应占溢利： 258亿元，预期为310亿元，同比增长10%。

这一结果标志着腾讯在经历了连续的负增长和持平季度后强劲反弹。该公司在其收益中表示，它受益于中国国内消费的稳健复苏，中国终于在 12 月开始放宽其激进的 Covid-19 限制。

腾讯在周三的报告中表示，净利润“以更快的速度增长，反映了积极的收入组合转变、运营效率和轻松的基期”。

投资者关注中国经济的重新开放是否会提振包括腾讯在内的中国科技巨头。中国经济一季度增长4.5%，创一年来最快增速。

作为从 2020 年底开始对中国国内科技行业进行更广泛监管收紧的一部分，中国科技行业作为一个整体面临着严格的审查，并从该国最大的公司中蒸发了超过 1 万亿美元的资产。

但最近，有迹象表明中央政府正在软化对腾讯、阿里巴巴和滴滴等互联网巨头的立场。

2021 年，中国监管机构冻结了对新视频游戏发行的批准，这对腾讯造成了严重影响。然而，在过去几个月里，北京放松了对该行业的控制，批准发行更多影片。

在国内游戏市场更加严峻的情况下，腾讯加强了对国际市场的关注。

腾讯是全球科技企业的主要所有者和投资者，由于北京仍对国内科技公司的规模保持高度警惕，腾讯一直在减持部分股权投资。

瑞士当局在 3 月的一个周末促成了瑞银对瑞士信贷的争议性紧急救助，救助金额为 30 亿瑞士法郎（33.7 亿美元）。

瑞士银行估计其紧急收购瑞士信贷造成的财务损失约为 170 亿美元 ，根据一份监管文件，并表示匆忙的交易可能影响了其尽职调查。

在周二深夜向美国证券交易委员会 (SEC) 提交的一份新文件中，这家瑞士银行业巨头表示，新合并实体的资产和负债的公允价值调整带来的总负面影响约为 130 亿美元，潜在影响为 40 亿美元受到诉讼和监管成本的打击。

然而，瑞银还预计通过从所谓的“负商誉”中一次性获得 348 亿美元的收益来抵消这一影响，“负商誉”是指以远低于其真实价值的成本收购资产。

瑞士当局在 3 月的一个周末促成了该银行以 30 亿瑞士法郎（34 亿美元）的价格紧急收购其陷入困境的国内竞争对手，瑞士信贷在大量客户提取存款和股价暴跌的情况下濒临崩溃边缘价格。

在修改后的 F-4 文件中，瑞银还强调，它被迫进行尽职调查的时间很短，这可能影响了它在收购前“全面评估瑞士信贷的资产和负债”的能力。

该文件显示，瑞士政府当局于 3 月 15 日与瑞银接洽，同时考虑是否开始出售瑞士信贷，以“稳定市场并避免金融体系蔓延的可能性”。该银行必须在 3 月 19 日之前进行尽职调查并做出决定。

瑞银CEO：瑞信交易没有风险
Squawk Box 欧洲

瑞银表示：“如果尽职调查的情况影响了瑞银集团全面考虑瑞信负债和弱点的能力，那么瑞银集团可能会同意一项比其预期的困难和风险大得多的救援行动。”在文件的风险因素部分。

虽然这被强调为潜在风险，但瑞银首席执行官塞尔吉奥埃尔莫蒂上个月告诉 CNBC，瑞士信贷的交易没有风险，并将创造长期利益。

该交易最具争议的方面是监管机构 FINMA 决定在持股前取消瑞士信贷约 170 亿美元的额外一级 (AT1) 债券，这违反了传统的减记顺序，并导致 AT1 债券持有人采取法律行动。

周二提交的文件显示，瑞银战略委员会于 2022 年 10 月开始评估瑞士信贷，因为其竞争对手的财务状况正在恶化。由于流动性担忧，这家长期苦苦挣扎的银行在 2022 年底经历了大规模的净资产外流。

瑞银战略委员会在 2 月份得出结论，收购瑞士信贷“不可取”，该行继续分析此类交易的财务和法律影响，以防情况恶化到瑞士当局要求瑞银的地步介入。

瑞银上周宣布，交易合法完成后， 瑞士信贷首席执行官 Ulrich Koerner 将加入新合并实体的执行董事会，预计将在未来几周内完成。

该集团将作为一个“综合银行集团”运营，瑞士信贷在可预见的未来将保持其品牌独立性，因为瑞银 (UBS) 正在进行分阶段整合。

由于投资者等待国会领导人与总统乔·拜登就美国债务上限进行的谈判取得进展的消息，周三上午股票期货小幅走高。

与道琼斯工业平均指数挂钩的期货上涨 45 点，或 0.14%。标准普尔 500 指数期货和纳斯达克 100 指数期货分别上涨 0.19% 和 0.23%。

白宫周二表示，拜登已指示工作人员每天就悬而未决的问题开会。白宫表示，鉴于谈判，总统还取消了即将到来的国际访问的第二站。

CFRA Research 首席投资策略师 Sam Stovall 表示：“人们将试图预测下一个头条新闻是什么。” “事关重大，不幸的是，对于会发生什么，我们没有多少可以猜测的。”

在周二的例会上，对违约可能性的担忧打压了投资者。 道指以 1% 的跌幅领跌主要股指，其次是标准普尔 500指数和纳斯达克综合指数分别下跌约0.6%及0.2%。

财政部长珍妮特耶伦重申她的警告，政府需要立即提高限额，因为该国最早可能在 6 月 1 日面临违约。

道指成员Home Depot的季度收入令人失望且全年业绩预期较低在周二的交易中也削弱了投资者的情绪。在经济方面，4 月份的零售额 低于接受道琼斯调查的经济学家的预期。

除了跟踪债务上限谈判的任何更新外，投资者还将关注周三的房屋开工和建筑许可数据。零售公司目标和TJX 两家公司都定于周三上午公布季度收益。

1小时前

欧洲市场周三低开

由于投资者密切关注美国的债务上限谈判，欧洲市场周三开盘走低。

泛欧斯托克 600 指数开盘下跌 0.2%，大多数板块和主要交易所均处于下跌区域。金融服务跌幅最大，下跌 1.3%，其次是汽车，下跌 0.9%。医疗保健以 0.1% 的涨幅逆势而上。

— 汉娜·沃德-格伦顿

4 小时前

经济数据不佳，人民币升值 7 大关

离岸人民币兑美元汇率进一步走弱至 7.0061，周三上午 2023 年首次突破 7 大关。

在岸人民币兑美元汇率也下跌 0.18% 至 6.9913，因投资者进一步消化了周二低于预期的中国经济数据。

据路透社计算，中国房价下跌，同比下跌 0.2%，而上月下跌 0.8%。

——李智惠

8 小时前

新加坡非石油国内出口在 4 月份意外月度增长，总贸易

新加坡 4 月份非石油国内出口较上月增长 2.7%，与路透社调查的经济学家预期的收缩 3% 相比，出人意料。

然而，与去年同期相比，非石油国内出口下降了 9.8%，高于经济学家预期的 9.4%。

这主要是由于对中国大陆、台湾和马来西亚的出口下降，尽管对美国、欧盟和韩国的出口有所增长。

新加坡 4 月份的贸易总额降至 1003 亿新元，同比下降 18.8%，延续了 3 月份 8.6% 的跌幅。

与 2022 年 4 月相比，出口总额下降 18.1%，进口总额收缩 19.5%。

— 林惠洁

7 小时前

拜登缩短行程 悉尼四方会议取消

据路透社报道，澳大利亚总理安东尼·艾博年 (Anthony Albanese) 表示， 四方领导人下周不会继续在悉尼举行会议。

澳大利亚定于5 月 24 日主办美国、印度和日本的 2023 年四方领导人峰会。

此前，美国总统拜登缩短亚洲之行返回美国与国会领导人就债务上限进行谈判。

——李智惠

西部联盟股价在盘后交易中上涨

西联股份在该银行表示截至 5 月 12 日本季度的存款增长超过 20 亿美元后，该银行在延长交易中上涨了约 7%。

新数据出现在周二提交给美国证券交易委员会的一份投资者更新报告中。

这比截至5 月 9 日的季度 18 亿美元的存款增长有所增加。

CNBC

是德科技因盈利强于预期而上涨

科技股是德科技在强劲的季度收益报告和本季度指引的支持下，盘后上涨超过 7%。

在其第二财季，该公司报告每股收益为 2.12 美元，不计项目，收入为 13.9 亿美元。相比之下，FactSet 调查的分析师预计每股收益为 1.96 美元，收入略低于 13.8 亿美元。

对于本季度，该公司表示预计本季度每股收益在 2 美元至 2.06 美元之间，而分析师预测为 1.96 美元。是德科技预计本季度的收入在 13.7 亿美元至 13.9 亿美元之间，这一范围包含华尔街普遍预期的 13.8 亿美元。

— 亚历克斯·哈林

道指自 3 月 30 日以来首次收于 50 日移动均线下方

道指周二收于关键门槛以下的交易时段。

30 种股票指数下跌 336.46 点，或 1.01%，收于 33,012.14。它收于 50 天移动平均线 33,143.18 下方，但盘中已跌破该门槛。

CNBC

50 日移动平均线是资产或指数交易位置的短期技术指标。收盘价低于该水平可能预示着潜在的下行变化。

-达拉梅尔卡多，吉娜弗兰科拉

10 小时前

在对本季度给出疲软预期后，Doximity 在盘后交易中下滑

医疗软件股票Doximity 在发布本季度的疲软指引后，在延长交易中下跌超过 8%。

该公司表示，预计第一财季的收入将在 1.065 亿美元至 1.075 亿美元之间，调整后的 EBITDA 将在 3900 万至 4000 万美元之间。这两项估计均低于普遍预期，FactSet 调查的分析师预计收入为 1180 万美元，调整后的 EBITDA 为 4540 万美元。

这盖过了第四财季的业绩。该公司报告不包括项目的每股收益为 20 美分，高于分析师预期的 17 美分。收入也超出预期，达到 1.11 亿美元，高于预期的 1.101 亿美元。调整后的 EBITDA 为 4890 万美元，高于普遍预期的 45.7 美元。

对于整个财年，该公司表示预计收入在 5 亿至 5.06 亿美元之间，这一范围包含华尔街估计的 5.018 亿美元。该公司预计今年调整后的 EBITDA 将在 2.16 亿美元至 2.22 亿美元之间，而分析师预计为 2.157 亿美元。

— 亚历克斯·哈林

与道琼斯指数、标准普尔 500 指数和纳斯达克 100 指数挂钩的期货均上涨约 0.1%。

俄罗斯似乎正在加倍努力夺取乌克兰东部的巴赫穆特，乌克兰武装部队周三表示，俄罗斯军队继续集中力量夺取莱曼、阿夫迪夫卡和马林卡周围被围困的城镇和附近地区。

在行动更新中，乌克兰武装部队总参谋部表示，在过去 24 小时内，这些地区记录了 55 次交战。 “巴赫穆特和马林卡仍处于敌对行动的中心，”乌克兰军方周三表示。

其他消息方面，周三是俄罗斯和乌克兰重要的谷物出口协议到期前的倒数第二天。该协议由土耳其和联合国促成，自战争开始以来已允许数百万吨农产品离开乌克兰港口，有助于缓解全球食品价格上涨。

这张鸟瞰图显示了 2022 年 8 月 9 日在土耳其伊斯坦布尔，俄罗斯、乌克兰、土耳其和联合国联合协调中心的代表在检查该船时的“荣耀”号粮船。
阿纳多卢机构 |阿纳多卢机构 |盖蒂图片社

俄罗斯威胁要退出该协议，因为其本国粮食和化肥出口面临障碍。

30 分钟前

最后一艘离开乌克兰的船因为黑海粮食交易的命运掌握在俄罗斯手中

根据联合国斡旋的黑海协议，一艘干货船从乌克兰运输谷物的鸟瞰图。
阿纳多卢机构 |盖蒂图片社

联合国发言人表示，根据一项允许乌克兰谷物安全出口黑海的协议，最后一艘船将于周三离开乌克兰的一个港口，前一天俄罗斯可能会因其谷物和化肥出口障碍退出该协议。

去年 7 月，联合国和土耳其促成了为期 120 天的黑海协议，以帮助解决因莫斯科入侵世界主要粮食出口国之一乌克兰而加剧的全球粮食危机。

莫斯科同意在 11 月将黑海协定再延长 120 天，但随后在 3 月又同意延长 60 天 - 至 5 月 18 日 - 除非满足其自身农产品出口的一系列要求。

为了在 7 月说服俄罗斯允许黑海谷物出口，联合国同时同意在三年内帮助莫斯科运送自己的农产品。

据俄罗斯媒体报道，克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫 (Dmitry Peskov) 周二对记者说：“关于我们在交易中的部分仍有很多悬而未决的问题。现在必须做出决定。”

来自俄罗斯、乌克兰、土耳其和联合国的高级官员上周在伊斯坦布尔举行会议，讨论黑海协定。联合国发言人斯蒂芬·杜加里克周二表示：“接触在不同层面上进行。我们显然处于微妙的阶段。”

土耳其外交部长梅夫鲁特恰武什奥卢上周表示，他认为该协议至少可以再延长两个月。

虽然俄罗斯的食品和化肥出口不受西方在 2022 年 2 月入侵乌克兰后实施的制裁的约束，但莫斯科表示，对支付、物流和保险的限制构成了运输障碍。

美国拒绝了俄罗斯的申诉。美国驻联合国大使琳达·托马斯-格林菲尔德上周表示：“它出口的粮食和化肥与全面入侵前的水平相同，甚至更高。”

— 路透社

苏丹喀土穆 - 2023 年 5 月 6 日：在与准军事快速支援部队的持续战斗中，苏丹陆军士兵走近驻扎在喀土穆南部街道上的装甲车。
法新社通过盖蒂图片社

苏丹两个军事派别在首都喀土穆爆发战斗一个月后，国际斡旋在沙特阿拉伯进行的和平谈判没有取得任何解决方案。

连日来，空袭和大炮继续袭击该国首都及周边地区，暴力事件也 波及到西部长期受困的达尔富尔地区。

国际救援委员会 (IRC) 周一表示，战斗已造成 600 多人丧生，5,000 多人受伤。预计实际死亡人数要高得多。近一百万人逃离家园，既有逃往苏丹境内的地方，也有越过边境逃往邻国。

Meanwhile, those who have stayed put often have no access to essentials despite a commitment from the two warring factions to restore access to food and electricity. Prices of food and fuel have soared, exacerbating malnutrition and hammering the local economy.

Warring generals Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, leader of the Sudanese Armed Forces, and Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo (or "Hemedti"), leader of the Rapid Support Forces, show no signs of halting the conflict as they vie for total control of the state's military and government, natural resources and 46 million inhabitants.

The US, UN and Saudi Arabia are brokering talks between the two sides, though tentative cease-fires and commitments to allow humanitarian corridors into the sprawling country have collapsed almost immediately.

'The needs are immense'

The IRC warned Monday that the humanitarian situation will continue to deteriorate unless all parties involved prioritize the protection of civilians.

"We know there are many uncertainties for people right now, but one thing that's clear is the needs are immense, immediate and will be for a long time," said IRC Vice President for East Africa Kurt Tjossem.

"The longer they remain in these conditions, the more vulnerable they become to disease, hunger, and other hardships."

Things have come a long way from 2021 when Burhan and Hemedti led a military coup that ousted the civilian government of Abdalla Hamdok. Since then, the SAF and RSF had been sharing power in Khartoum to facilitate what most Sudanese citizens hoped would be a transition back to civilian rule.

The World Bank and several global powers froze aid to the country after the military takeover, honoring calls from civilians not to legitimize its leadership.

However, Burhan and Hemedti's divergent political visions were never reconciled, and the fragile power-sharing arrangement began to unravel in early April, culminating in the breakout of a full-scale conflict in Khaartoum on April 15.

METEMA, Ethiopia - May 5, 2023: Refugees who crossed from Sudan to Ethiopia wait in line to register at IOM (International organization for Migration) in Metema, Ethiopia.
Amanuel Sileshi / AFP via Getty Images

In a speech at the UN Human Rights Council last week, UK Minister for International Development and Africa Andrew Mitchell stressed the importance of the international community in helping to revert Sudan to the "political track" by sending a "united message of concern and of horror" and breaking the "cycle of impunity in Sudan."

Yet many Sudanese believe that despite the efforts of various regional and international bodies, the Jeddah talks — lacking a substantial civilian voice and the threat of harsh international sanctions against the generals and their respective inner circles — will not be part of the solution.

Rewarding 'belligerence'

Sudanese-Australian writer, broadcaster and activist Yassmin Abdel-Magied told CNBC last week that global leaders had inadvertently given Burhan and Hemedti political legitimacy and rewarded their "belligerence," leaving the majority of Sudanese who long for civilian government unrepresented.

Both the SAF and RSF benefit from financial and political support from foreign powers including Egypt, the UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Libya, the University of Cambridge's Associate Professor Sharath Srinivasan told CNBC last month. While Benjamin Hunter from risk consultancy Verisk Maplecroft, said these close relationships make it more difficult for a resolution to the conflict to be found imminently.

Targeted and collaborative efforts by the international community to exert pressure on the countries supporting Sudan's military factions were needed, Abdel-Magied said.

"If [their] resource[s], financial and otherwise, can be throttled, then we might actually be able to find the right kind of incentive that's going to make them stop fighting," she told CNBC via telephone.

In order for Sudan to move forward, Abdel-Magied said there needs to be accountability for past government atrocities. Importantly, she said this effort should be led by Sudanese civil society figureheads — not external states seeking a quick fix.

"History is littered with the results of unintended consequences because of foreign states thinking 'if we support this person, this outcome will happen' and not thinking two, three generations ahead," she added.

One way to give a voice to Sudanese civilians could be through resistance committees, according to Abdel-Magied: informal neighborhood networks that have spearheaded the country's pro-democracy movement since the fall of dictator Omar al-Bashir in 2019.

These groups have been working alongside NGOs and civil society groups to facilitate evacuations, provide food and clean up damaged and looted hospitals, and Abdel-Magied suggested that a small selection of delegates could represent collective civilian interests at the peace talks.

"The framework is already there" to raise the voice of the Sudanese people beyond those with a vested interest in maintaining the status quo, she added.

State failure on the cards?

Without setting in motion the chain of events that would rebuild Sudan's political and military structure from the ground up, Abdel-Magied said many Sudanese fear that "there is no obvious endpoint" to the fighting.

"Sudan was not in a great place even before this started and what I don't want to see is another 30 years of dysfunction because that's kind of what will happen if the fall isn't arrested, and then you're looking at something that's much more difficult," she said.

"We're not there yet. It's not inevitable, the state completely and utterly failing, and so we can actually stop that from happening. And all we as civilians can do is urge those with the power to act fast enough, and not with haste but with intentional diligent thought through action in order to prevent the worst case scenario."

The news marks a vote of confidence for the insurance technology space at a time when it faces tough macroeconomic headwinds.

Wefox is a Berlin, Germany-based firm focused on personal insurance products, such as home insurance, motor insurance and personal liability insurance. Rather than underwriting claims itself, the company connects its users with brokers and partner insurance firms through an online platform.

Founded in 2015, it competes with the likes of US digital insurer Lemonade and German firm GetSafe, as well as established insurance incumbents like Allianz .

Wefox said it raised the fresh funds through a combination of debt financing and fresh equity. Of the $110 million total, $55 million is in the form of a credit facility from banking giants JPMorgan and Barclays. A further of $55 million equity investment was led by Squarepoint Capital, a global investment management firm with $75.7 billion in assets under management.

"It's a new type of financing for a growth company," Julian Teicke, Wefox's CEO and co-founder, told CNBC in an interview. "Risk investors, equity investors, they understand, they want to take risk."

"Banks typically don't, so for them it was really important to understand our path towards profitability and the maturity of our business," he added.

The company said it maintained its $4.5 billion valuation from a July funding round — somewhat rare in today's market, with many fintechs seeing their valuations slump drastically.

Wefox's announcement comes as fintech and the technology industry as a whole grapple with a harsher economic environment, finding it more difficult to raise funding.

Higher interest rates have seen investors reevaluate growth-oriented tech businesses, with equity markets — and fintech in particular — taking a beating. In the public markets, US firm Lemonade has seen its shares drop 23% in the past 12 months, though the stock is up 13% so far in 2023.

Layoffs have also plagued the fintech space. On Tuesday, money transfer firm Zepz told CNBC it was letting 420 employees go, or 16% of its total workforce, in the latest round of redundancies to hit the sector.

The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, too, has darkened the outlook. The tech-focused lender collapsed earlier this year after its startup and venture capital clients fled in a panic due to capitalization concerns.

Despite the headwinds facing the wider tech industry, Teicke says he believes Wefox is "crisis-resistant." In the first quarter of 2023, Wefox saw its revenues almost double year-over-year. The company anticipates it will reach profitability by the end of this year.

Teicke also said Wefox hasn't faced the same pressures to lay off staff. Instead, it has shifted its priorities, he said, "doubling down on things that work and stopping things that don't make sense."

For instance, Teicke said Wefox was focusing on its broker partnership model and its so-called "affinity" method of distribution, where it sells its insurance software to other businesses for a subscription fee — for example, an online car dealer adding car insurance at the point of sale.

The fresh funds will go towards investing in Wefox's affinity program and technology platform, the company said.

Teicke said Wefox is also investing heavily in artificial intelligence, which has become a hot area of tech recently following the rise of viral AI chatbot ChatGPT. Wefox mainly uses AI to automate policy applications and customer service.

The company has three tech hubs in Paris, Barcelona, and Milan dedicated to AI.
